concepts.name: Chemical Compound
concepts.definition: A substance formed when two or more chemical elements are chemically bonded together. Most elements in nature are found as compounds.

concepts.name: Ionic Compound
concepts.definition: A compound, typically formed between a metal and a non-metal, composed of ions held together by electrostatic forces. They are often crystalline solids with high melting points and conduct electricity when molten or dissolved in water.

concepts.name: Covalent Compound
concepts.definition: A compound, also known as a molecular compound, formed by the sharing of electrons between atoms, typically non-metals. They can be solids, liquids, or gases at room temperature and generally have low melting points.

concepts.name: Chemical Bond
concepts.definition: The forces that attract and hold atoms to each other in compounds, primarily involving the interaction between valence electrons.

concepts.name: Ionic Bond
concepts.definition: A type of chemical bond formed through the electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions, which are created when one atom transfers one or more electrons to another atom. It typically occurs when the electronegativity difference is greater than 1.7.

concepts.name: Covalent Bond
concepts.definition: A type of chemical bond formed when two atoms share one or more pairs of electrons. It typically occurs between non-metals when the electronegativity difference is less than 1.7.

concepts.name: Electronegativity (EN)
concepts.definition: A measure of an atom's ability to attract electrons in a chemical bond. The difference in electronegativity (ΔEN) between two atoms is used to predict the type of bond they will form.

concepts.name: Octet Rule
concepts.definition: A chemical rule of thumb stating that atoms tend to bond in such a way that they each have eight electrons in their valence shell, giving them the same electron configuration as a noble gas.

concepts.name: Isoelectronic
concepts.definition: A term used to describe two atoms or ions that have the same electron configuration.

concepts.name: Lewis Structure
concepts.definition: A diagram that shows the bonding between atoms of a molecule and the lone pairs of electrons that may exist in the molecule, helping to visualize electron transfer or sharing.

concepts.name: Pure Covalent Bond
concepts.definition: A covalent bond in which the electrons are shared equally between two atoms of the same or similar electronegativity, resulting in an electronegativity difference of approximately 0.

concepts.name: Polar Covalent Bond
concepts.definition: A type of covalent bond where the bonding electron pair is shared unequally between two atoms due to a significant difference in their electronegativities (typically between 0.5 and 1.7), resulting in partial positive (δ+) and partial negative (δ-) charges on the atoms.

concepts.name: Double Bond
concepts.definition: A covalent bond in which two pairs of electrons are shared between two atoms to satisfy the octet rule.

concepts.name: Triple Bond
concepts.definition: A covalent bond in which three pairs of electrons are shared between two atoms to satisfy the octet rule.

concepts.name: Intramolecular Forces
concepts.definition: The strong forces, such as covalent bonds, that hold atoms together within a molecule.

concepts.name: Intermolecular Forces
concepts.definition: The relatively weak forces of attraction that exist between molecules, which determine properties like melting and boiling points for covalent compounds.

concepts.name: Metallic Bonding
concepts.definition: A type of chemical bonding where metal atoms release their valence electrons to a shared 'sea' of free electrons, which holds the resulting metal ions together.

concepts.name: Alloy
concepts.definition: A homogeneous mixture of two or more metals held together by metallic bonds.

concepts.name: Molecular Shape
concepts.definition: The three-dimensional arrangement of atoms within a molecule, which is determined by the repulsion between electron pairs (both bonding and lone pairs).

concepts.name: Lone Pair
concepts.definition: A pair of valence electrons that is not shared with another atom in a covalent bond and influences the molecule's shape.

concepts.name: Bonding Pair
concepts.definition: A pair of electrons that is shared between two atoms in a covalent bond.

concepts.name: Polar Molecule
concepts.definition: A molecule that has a net separation of charge, creating a positive and a negative end (a dipole), due to the combination of polar covalent bonds and an asymmetrical molecular shape.

concepts.name: Non-polar Molecule
concepts.definition: A molecule that does not have a net separation of charge, either because its bonds are non-polar or because its symmetrical shape causes the effects of its polar bonds to cancel out.

concepts.name: Chemical Formula
concepts.definition: A shorthand notation using chemical symbols and subscripts to indicate the elements that make up a compound and the ratio of atoms of each element.

concepts.name: Valence
concepts.definition: A number assigned to an element that describes its bonding capacity, indicating how many electrons it tends to lose, gain, or share when forming bonds.

concepts.name: Polyatomic Ion
concepts.definition: A charged ion composed of two or more atoms covalently bonded together that acts as a single unit in chemical reactions.

concepts.name: Zero Sum Rule
concepts.definition: A rule stating that for a neutral chemical compound, the sum of the positive valences and negative valences of all atoms or ions must equal zero.

concepts.name: Chemical Nomenclature
concepts.definition: The system of rules used for naming chemical compounds, developed by IUPAC to provide a unique and descriptive name for every substance.

concepts.name: Binary Compound
concepts.definition: A compound that contains exactly two different elements.

concepts.name: Tertiary Compound
concepts.definition: A compound that contains three different elements, often consisting of a metal or polyatomic cation and a polyatomic anion.

concepts.name: Stock System
concepts.definition: A method of chemical nomenclature where the valence of a metal that can form more than one type of ion is indicated by a Roman numeral in parentheses following the element's name.

concepts.name: Sodium Chloride (NaCl)
concepts.definition: A typical ionic compound, commonly known as table salt, formed from the transfer of an electron from sodium to chlorine.

concepts.name: Carbon Dioxide (CO₂)
concepts.definition: A covalent compound with a linear, symmetrical shape, making it a non-polar molecule despite having polar bonds.

concepts.name: Water (H₂O)
concepts.definition: A covalent compound with a bent molecular shape and polar O-H bonds, making it a highly polar molecule.

concepts.name: Ammonia (NH₃)
concepts.definition: A covalent compound with a pyramidal shape, which makes it a polar molecule.
